def_en: You refer to someone's mind when talking about their thoughts. For example, if you say that something is in your mind, you mean that you are thinking about it, and if you say that something is at the back of your mind, you mean that you are aware of it, although you are not thinking about it very much.

def_cn: 头脑，大脑(指思考和推理的能力)
def_en: Your mind is your ability to think and reason.
If you have a particular type of mind, you have a particular way of thinking which is part of your character, or a result of your education or professional training.

def_cn: 有才智的人;富有想象力的人;精英
def_en: You can refer to someone as a particular kind of mind as a way of saying that they are clever, intelligent, or imaginative.
minded; -minded; frame of mind; state of mind;
If you tell someone to bear something in mind or to keep something in mind, you are reminding or warning them about something important which they should remember.
If something brings another thing to mind or calls another thing to mind, it makes you think of that other thing, usually because it is similar in some way.
If you cast your mind back to a time in the past, you think about what happened then.

def_cn: 对…不予考虑;对…置若罔闻
def_en: If you close your mind to something, you deliberately do not think about it or pay attention to it.

def_cn: （使）改变主意;（使）改变决定
def_en: If you change your mind, or if someone or something changes your mind, you change a decision you have made or an opinion that you had.

def_cn: 突然想起;(想法)一下子冒出来
def_en: If something comes to mind or springs to mind, you think of it without making any effort.

def_cn: (想法)掠过心头，被想到，进入脑海
def_en: If you say that an idea or possibility never crossed your mind, you mean that you did not think of it.
If you see something in your mind's eye, you imagine it and have a clear picture of it in your mind.
If you have a mind to do something, you want, intend, or choose to do it.

def_cn: 很想做(作为一种警告或声明，实际很可能不会做)
def_en: If you say that you have a good mind to do something or have half a mind to do it, you are threatening or announcing that you have a strong desire to do it, although you probably will not do it.
If you ask someone what they have in mind, you want to know in more detail about an idea or wish they have.
If you have it in mind to do something, you intend or want to do it.

def_cn: 以…为目标(或理由、基础);考虑到
def_en: If you do something with a particular thing in mind, you do it with that thing as your aim or as the reason or basis for your action.

def_cn: (疾病等)只是凭空想象的，完全由心理引起的
def_en: If you say that something such as an illness is all in the mind, you mean that it relates to someone's feelings or attitude, rather than having any physical cause.
If you know your own mind, you are sure about your opinions, and are not easily influenced by other people.
If you say that someone is losing their mind, you mean that they are becoming mad.
If you make up your mind or make your mind up, you decide which of a number of possible things you will have or do.

def_cn: 思想支配物质(指某人似乎能够用其思想控制事情、物体或自身身体状况)
def_en: You can use the expression mind over matter to describe situations in which a person seems to be able to control events, physical objects, or the condition of their own body using their mind.
If a number of people are of one mind ,of like mind, or of the same mind, they all agree about something.

def_cn: 不再忧虑;心中的石头落地
def_en: If you say that something that happens is a load off your mind or a weight off your mind, you mean that it causes you to stop worrying, for example because it solves a problem that you had.
If something is on your mind, you are worried or concerned about it and think about it a lot.
If your mind is on something or you have your mind on something, you are thinking about that thing.

def_cn: 开明的思想;无先入之见的心态
def_en: If you have an open mind, you avoid forming an opinion or making a decision until you know all the facts.

def_cn: 使思想开放；使更愿意接受(或尝试)(新事物)
def_en: If something opens your mind to new ideas or experiences, it makes you more willing to accept them or try them.
If you say that someone is out of their mind, you mean that they are mad or very foolish.

def_cn: (用于强调感受)极其，非常
def_en: If you say that someone is out of their mind with a feeling such as worry or fear, you are emphasizing that they are extremely worried or afraid.

def_cn: 烦得要命/吓得丢了魂/在毒品作用下变得飘飘然
def_en: If you say that someone is, for example, bored out of their mind ,scared out of their mind, or stoned out of their mind, you are emphasizing that they are extremely bored, scared, or affected by drugs.
If you put your mind to something, you start making an effort to do it.

def_cn: 使想起，使联想起(类似或相关的事)
def_en: If something puts you in mind of something else, it reminds you of it because it is similar to it or is associated with it.

def_cn: 读懂…的思想;看出…的心思
def_en: If you can read someone's mind, you know what they are thinking without them saying anything.
To put someone's mind at rest or set their mind at rest means to stop them worrying about something.

def_cn: 心智正常(而不会做某事)
def_en: If you say that nobody in their right mind would do a particular thing, you are emphasizing that it is an irrational thing to do and you would be surprised if anyone did it.
If you set your mind on something or have your mind set on it, you are determined to do it or obtain it.
If something slips your mind, you forget it.
If you speak your mind, you say firmly and honestly what you think about a situation, even if this may offend or upset people.

def_cn: 被牢记在心；印在脑海中
def_en: If something sticks in your mind, it remains firmly in your memory.

def_cn: 使暂时忘记(某一问题或不愉快的情况)
def_en: If something takes your mind off a problem or unpleasant situation, it helps you to forget about it for a while.
You say or write to my mind to indicate that the statement you are making is your own opinion.

def_cn: （尤指在两种行动选择间）犹豫不决，拿不定主意（亦可使用of two minds，尤见于美国英语）
def_en: If you are in two minds, you are uncertain about what to do, especially when you have to choose between two courses of action. The expression of two minds is also used, especially in American English.
to give someone a piece of your mind→see: piece;  presence of mind→see: presence;  presence of mind→see: out of mind;  out of sight→see: sight;
If you do not mind something, you are not annoyed or bothered by it.

def_cn: (征求对方同意或者请求对方做某事时的礼貌说法)你是否介意
def_en: You use mind in the expressions 'do you mind?' and 'would you mind?' as a polite way of asking permission or asking someone to do something.
If someone does not mind what happens or what something is like, they do not have a strong preference for any particular thing.
If you tell someone to mind something, you are warning them to be careful not to hurt themselves or other people, or damage something.
You use mind when you are reminding someone to do something or telling them to be careful not to do something.
If you mind a child or something such as a shop or luggage, you look after it, usually while the person who owns it or is usually responsible for it is somewhere else.
If you are offered something or offered a choice and you say 'I don't mind', you are saying politely that you will be happy with any of the things offered.

def_cn: (接受某人给予的东西，尤指接受饮料或食物时)好的，可以
def_en: You can say 'I don't mind if I do' as a way of accepting something that someone has offered you, especially food or drink.

def_cn: (用于认为自己在场可能使某人尴尬时)不用考虑我，不用在意我
def_en: You say 'Don't mind me' to apologize for your presence when you think that it might embarrass someone, and to tell them to carry on with what they were doing or about to do.

def_cn: (认为别人的行为可能冒犯谈话的对象时，为别人的行为表示道歉)别在意(他或他们)
def_en: You use don't mind in expressions such as don't mind him or don't mind them to apologize for someone else's behaviour when you think it might have offended the person you are speaking to.
Some people say 'Mind how you go' when they are saying goodbye to someone who is leaving.

def_cn: (尤用于生气地拒绝提议或表示不愿做某事)如果你不介意
def_en: People use the expression if you don't mind when they are rejecting an offer or saying that they do not want to do something, especially when they are annoyed.

def_cn: (用于强调补充信息，尤指新信息对之前所说的话进行解释或形成对比)请注意
def_en: You use mind you to emphasize a piece of information that you are adding, especially when the new information explains what you have said or contrasts with it. Some people use mind in a similar way.

def_cn: (尤指对小孩说的话)注意语言/注意说话/注意态度
def_en: If you tell someone, especially a child, to mind their language ,mind their tongue, or mind their manners, you are telling them to speak or behave properly and politely.
You say never mind when you are emphasizing that something is not serious or important, especially when someone is upset about it or is saying sorry to you.

def_cn: 不用了;不必担心;不用着急
def_en: You use never mind to tell someone that they need not do something or worry about something, because it is not important or because you will do it yourself.

def_cn: (常用于否定陈述句后)更不用说
def_en: You use never mind after a statement, often a negative one, to indicate that the statement is even more true of the person, thing, or situation that you are going to mention next.
You use never you mind to tell someone not to ask about something because it is not their concern or they should not know about it.

def_cn: (用于强调将要说的话)我不介意告诉你
def_en: You can say 'I don't mind telling you' to emphasize the statement you are making.
If you say that you wouldn't mind something, you mean that you would quite like it.
to mind your own business→see: business;
